sent: Athena LaTocha is a Hunkpapa Lakota artist focusing on unique ways of making landscape paintings and the relationship of man-made and natural landscapes.
Old Corn Meal is one of the earliest known African Americans to have had a documented influence on the development of blackface minstrelsy specifically and American popular music in general.

In 1921, Eubie Blake and his long-time collaborator Noble Sissle wrote Shuffle Along, one of the first Broadway musicals to be written and directed by African Americans.
The brutality of Emmett Till's murder and the fact that his killers were acquitted drew attention to the long history of violent persecution of African Americans in the United States.
Booker T. Washington's long-term goal was to end the disenfranchisement of the vast majority of African Americans, who then still lived in the South.

Matilda Evans, M.D., (May 13, 1872 - November 17, 1935) was the first African-American woman licensed to practice medicine in South Carolina and an advocate for improved health care for African Americans, particularly children.

Diom Roméo Saganash (born October 28, 1961) is a Canadian Cree lawyer and politician who served as the Member of Parliament (MP) for the Quebec riding of Abitibi-Baie-James-Nunavik-Eeyou from 2011 to 2019.
George Moses Horton's collection The Hope of Liberty was published in 1829; he is one of the few African Americans to have poetry published while still enslaved.

W.E.B. Du Bois referred to this group as the Talented Tenth, a concept under the umbrella of Racial uplift, and believed that African Americans needed the chances for advanced education to develop its leadership.

Sacagawea (/skwi/; also Sakakawea or Sacajawea; May c.1788 - December 20, 1812 or April 9, 1884) was a Lemhi Shoshone woman who, at age 16, met and helped the Lewis and Clark Expedition in achieving their chartered mission objectives by exploring the Louisiana Territory.

During the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration, Robert C. Weaver was one of 45 prominent African Americans appointed to positions and helped make up the Black Cabinet, an informal group of African-American public policy advisers.
In 1874, Edward Bouchet had become one of the first African Americans to graduate from Yale College.

A Louisiana Creole of mixed-race ancestry, Broyard was criticized by some black political figures for Anatole Broyard's decisions, as he had acted as an individual during a period of increased communal political activity by African Americans.
Fredebal, also spelled as Fredbal or Fredbalus, was a king of the Vandals during the 5th century.

Alcimus Ecdicius Avitus (c. 450 - February 5, 517/518 or 519) was a Latin poet and bishop of Vienne in Gaul.

Gaspard Bauhin or Caspar Bauhin (Latin: Casparus Bauhinus; 17 January 1560 - 5 December 1624), was a Swiss botanist whose Pinax theatri botanici (1623) described thousands of plants and classified them in a manner that draws comparisons to the later binomial nomenclature of Linnaeus.
Jordanes wrote in Late Latin rather than the classical Ciceronian Latin.
Alain de Lille (Alan of Lille) (Latin: Alanus ab Insulis; c. 1128Â - 1202/03) was a French theologian and poet.
Nausea is the Latin equivalent of Frederic Nausea's German name (grauen = to disgust, become ashen).
Johann Wigand (Latin: Jo(h)annes Wigandus; c. 1523 - 21 October 1587) was a German Lutheran cleric, Protestant reformer and theologian.
Girolamo Fracastoro (Latin: Hieronymus Fracastorius; c. 1476/8 - 6 August 1553) was an Italian physician, poet, and scholar in mathematics, geography and astronomy.

Georg Tannstetter's Latin name "Collimitius" is derived from limes meaning "border" and is a reference to his birth town: "Rain" is a German word for border or boundary.
At the age of 22 Jacob Bidermann wrote his first play Cenodoxus, in Latin, a dramatization of the popular Legend of the Doctor of Paris, (the Faust theme).

John III Sobieski (Polish: Jan III Sobieski; Lithuanian: Jonas III Sobieskis; Latin: Ioannes III Sobiscius; 17 August 1629 - 17 June 1696) was King of Poland and Grand Duke of Lithuania from 1674 until his death.
Martial has been called the greatest Latin epigrammatist, and is considered the creator of the modern epigram.
Conrad Gessner (/snr/; Latin: Conradus Gesnerus 26 March 1516 - 13 December 1565) was a Swiss physician, naturalist, bibliographer, and philologist.

Lelio Francesco Maria Sozzini, or simply Lelio (Latin: Laelius Socinus; 29 January 1525 - 4 May 1562), was an Italian Renaissance humanist and anti-Trinitarian reformer, and uncle of the better known Fausto Sozzini (Latin: Faustus Socinus) from whom the Polish Brethren and early English Unitarians came to be called "Socinians".

Julius Caesar Aranzi's books (in Latin) covered surgical techniques for many conditions, including hydrocephalus, nasal polyp, goitre and tumours to phimosis, ascites, haemorrhoids, anal abscess and fistulae.

The Frankfurt humanist Jakob Micyllus inspired Petrus Lotichius Secundus's interest in Latin poetry.
Johann Heinrich Ernesti (12 March 1652 - 16 October 1729) was a Saxon philosopher, Lutheran theologian, Latin classicist and poet.
Titus Lucretius Carus (/tats lukris/ TY-ts loo-KREE-shs; Latin:Â [tts lkret.s ka.rus]; c. 99 BCÂ - c. 55 BC) was a Roman poet and philosopher.

Saint Ignatius of Loyola (Basque: Ignazio Loiolakoa; Spanish: Ignacio de Loyola; Latin: Ignatius de Loyola; c. 23 October 1491 - 31 July 1556) was a Spanish Basque Catholic priest and theologian, who co-founded the religious order called the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) and became its first Superior General at Paris in  1541.

John Milton's desire for freedom extended into his style: he introduced new words (coined from Latin and Ancient Greek) to the English language, and was the first modern writer to employ unrhymed verse outside of the theatre or translations.
Adam of Bremen (Latin: Adamus Bremensis; German: Adam von Bremen) (Before 1050 - 12 October 1081/1085) was a German medieval chronicler.

Otto Walper (also Latin Otho Gual(t)perius; January 1, 1543 - December 28, 1624) was a German theologian and philosopher.

Gaspar Schott (German: Kaspar (or Caspar) Schott; Latin: Gaspar Schottus; 5 February 1608 - 22 May 1666) was a German Jesuit and scientist, specializing in the fields of physics, mathematics and natural philosophy, and known for his industry.

Hermann Witsius (Herman Wits or in Latin Hermannus Witsius; 12 February 1636 - 22 October 1708, aged 72) was a Dutch theologian.
Oliviero Carafa (10 March 1430 - 20 January 1511), in Latin: Oliverius Carafa, was an Italian cardinal and diplomat of the Renaissance.
Natale Conti or Latin Natalis Comes, also Natalis de Comitibus and French NoÃ«l le Comte (1520-1582) was an Italian mythographer, poet, humanist and historian.

Novatian was a noted theologian and writer, the first Roman theologian who used the Latin language, at a time when there was much debate about how to deal with Christians who had lapsed and wished to return, and the issue of penance.
Marcus Minucius Felix (died c. 250 AD in Rome) was one of the earliest of the Latin apologists for Christianity.
William of Malmesbury (Latin: Willelmus Malmesbiriensis; c.1095Â - c.1143) was the foremost English historian of the 12th century.

Ludwig Lavater's work on ghosts (De spectris ...) was one of the most frequently printed demonological works of the early modern period, going into at least nineteen early modern editions in German, Latin, French, English and Italian.
Lou Henry Hoover made extensive study of languages including Latin, Mandarin Chinese, Spanish, German, Italian and French.
Plautus's comedies are the earliest Latin literary works to have survived in their entirety.

Conrad Celtes (German: Konrad Celtes; Latin: Conradus Celtis (Protucius); 1 February 1459 - 4 February 1508) was a German humanist scholar and poet of the German Renaissance born in Franconia (nowadays part of Bavaria).
Albius Tibullus (c.55 BCÂ - 19 BC) was a Latin poet and writer of elegies.

Pietro Pomponazzi is sometimes known by his Latin name, Petrus Pomponatius.

Ovid was a contemporary of the older Virgil and Horace, with whom he is often ranked as one of the three canonical poets of Latin literature.

Claudius Claudianus, usually known in English as Claudian (/kldin/; c. 370 - c. 404 AD), was a Latin poet associated with the court of the emperor Honorius at Mediolanum (Milan), and particularly with the general Stilicho.
Josias Simmler (Josiah Simler; Latin: Iosias Simlerus) (6 November 1530 - 2 July 1576) was a Swiss theologian and classicist, author of the first book relating solely to the Alps.
Peter Damian (Latin: Petrus Damianus; Italian: Pietro or Pier Damiani; c.1007Â - 21 or 22 February 1072 or 1073) was a reforming Benedictine monk and cardinal in the circle of Pope LeoÂ IX.

Gilles de Corbeil (Latin: Egidius de Corbolio or Egidius Corboliensis; also Aegidius) was a French royal physician, teacher, and poet.
Karl or Carl Gottlob Zumpt (Latin: Carolus Timotheus Zumpt; 1 April 1792Â - 25 June 1849) was a German classical scholar known for Karl Gottlob Zumpt's work in the field of Latin philology.

David Hoeschel (also HÃ¶schel) (Latin: Hoeschelius) (8 April 1556, Augsburg - 19 October 1617, Augsburg) was a German librarian, editor and scholar.
Jordan of Saxony, (referred to in Latin as Jordanis, also known as de Alamania; c. 1190 - 1237), was one of the first leaders of the Dominican Order.

Gaius Valerius Catullus (/ktls/ k-TUL-s, Latin:Â [katlls]; c. 84 - c. 54 BC) was a Latin poet of the late Roman Republic who wrote chiefly in the neoteric style of poetry, which is about personal life rather than classical heroes.

Luigi Galvani (/Ã¦lvni/, also US: /l-/, Italian:Â [luidi alvani]; Latin: Aloysius Galvanus; 9 September 1737 - 4 December 1798) was an Italian physician, physicist, biologist and philosopher, who discovered animal electricity.
The Final Nexus is a 1988 Star Trek: The Original Series novel written by Gene DeWeese.
The Stonewall Columbus Pride Festival and Parade began in 1981, and has grown into the 2nd largest Pride event in the Midwest behind only Chicago.

Festac '77, also known as the Second World Black and African Festival of Arts and Culture (the first was in Dakar, 1966), was a major international festival held in Lagos, Nigeria, from 15 January 1977 to 12 February 1977.
Aramaic Music Festival is the first international Aramaic music festival, which was held in the  Syriac village of Tannourine in Mount Lebanon, Lebanon, year 2008 1-4 August for the Syriac people.
The Internationale Gartenausstellung 2017 (IGA 2017) was an international horticultural exhibition that took place in Berlin, Germany, in 2017.

sub_label: Nelson Mandela: An International Tribute for a Free South Africa
sent: Nelson Mandela: An International Tribute for a Free South Africa was a music concert that took place on 16 April 1990 at Wembley Stadium, Wembley Park, London, United Kingdom (UK) and was broadcast to more than 60 countries.
